Award.AwardTitle: Evolutionary Genomics of a Supergene Implicated in Social Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Project scientists will conduct whole-genome DNA sequencing and comparative genomic analyses on several species of fire ants to reveal the genetic determinants of variation in colony social organization. Fire ants are ideal models to learn about genes that influence complex social behavior because the biology of these pests is well known, genetic resources are available, and strict genetic control over variation in fundamental social traits has been documented. Project researchers will generate complete genome sequences for more than 140 specimens of native, South American fire ants and use statistical and comparative analyses to reconstruct the architecture and evolutionary history of the genomic region regulating social organization.

This research will have broad implications for evolutionary biologists seeking to understand the genetic bases of complex social behaviors. Description of a genomic region involved in a major social innovation using the fire ant model will advance understanding of the evolution of advanced social behavior as well as clarify the evolutionary origin of integrated gene complexes, which underlie such important biological phenomena as the origin of sex chromosomes and self-incompatibility. The information to be generated is essential for an improved understanding of the molecular basis of social life. Associated outreach and educational activities will inform the public about the evolution of social behavior and involve secondary school classrooms in citizen-science activities related to the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Variation in colony queen number in most fire ants is completely associated with variation at a single mendelian element marked by the gene Gp-9: inhabitants of single-queen (monogyne) colonies bear only B-like alleles at this locus while inhabitants of multiple-queen (polygyne) colonies bear b-like alleles as well. Gp- 9 is part of a “supergene” comprising a network of linked genes that are held together to regulate various features of the alternate social syndromes. By sequencing the entire genomes of a large number of specimens of South American fire ants (including the invasive Red Imported Fire Ant, Solenopsis invicta), we obtained high-quality genome assemblies of the supergene region, which allowed us to conduct other critical studies. Most important among these, the three inversions (with breakpoints) that collectively suppress recombination between the homologous B-like and b-like haplotypes were characterized, the evolutionary pathway by which the inversions were incorporated into the supergene was reconstructed, and the low rate of recombination between the supergene and homologous haplotypes was quantified. We also conducted several gene expression studies to complement the genome analyses. These revealed that the colony type (monogyne or polygyne) in which an ant queen is reared profoundly affects her gene expression profile. Large effects of the supergene also were detected, and these led to a list of candidate genes that may be involved in the development of specific social traits. The resulting knowledge of a large genomic region involved in regulating complex social behavior provides a foundation for understanding the evolution of highly derived social traits in other animals as well as for comprehending the evolution of supergenes, which underlie many complex phenotypes in nature.

Several other studies related to fire ant social evolution were completed under the auspices of this project. First, a large-scale laboratory study investigated the possible occurrence of meiotic drive during egg production in polygyne S. invicta queens from the USA. Meiotic drive is defined as the unequal transmission of the two alleles from a heterozygous parent to its gametes, transpiring during the process of gametogenesis. The b-like supergene shares several features in common with known drive elements, raising the question of whether it also may act as such a selfish genetic element favoring its own transmission during oogenesis. Large embryo progenies derived from 101 polygyne queens were collected and genotyped at three supergene-linked markers as well as at twelve loci not located on the supergene chromosome. Several types of statistical analysis indicated that the supergene region exhibits meiotic drive but, surprisingly, not always in the predicted direction. The results thus implicate a complex genetic system involving selfish drive elements in the b-like supergene capable of biasing their transmission during reproduction, coupled with suppressor loci in the homologous wild type or other chromosomes that evidently evolved to evade this unfair replication. Second, the cause of polygyny in the native fire ant Solenopsis geminata was investigated. Workers, queens, and males were collected from three Florida sites and were genotyped at 9-35 microsatellite loci, with mtDNA gene sequences obtained also for the females. The genetic data for the monogyne ants showed the expected standard reproductive mode of social Hymenoptera—one reproductive queen headed each colony, was singly mated to a haploid male, and produced daughters (of both castes) from fertilized diploid eggs and sons from unfertilized haploid eggs. In contrast, the data for the polygyne nests suggested that queens are produced sexually and workers asexually, with males of the monogyne form fertilizing the eggs that give rise to workers. This remarkable and peculiar reproductive system demonstrates that polygyne social organization can be achieved via multiple different routes in fire ants. Evidently, the transition to polygyny in Florida S. geminata occurred repeatedly by means of social conversion of monogyne founder groups accompanied by a switch to clonal queen production.

Broader impact achievements of the project include development of a website dedicated to describing concepts of social evolution and containing links to a library of fire ant behavioral videos that serve as a public information resource. Also, a school outreach component involved project scientists working with secondary school classrooms to describe and display various features of fire ant social behavior to illustrate the functioning of advanced insect societies. Students subsequently were brought to the PI’s lab to learn basic skills of molecular biology, and one was hired as a summer intern in the PI’s lab to give him relevant experience relating to STEM careers. This project also resulted in the scientific training of over a dozen undergraduate and graduate students.
